summary.p: May God assist [the ailing] Utinger. A victory of the Emperor would threaten the Confederates and, as is heard from Brabant, also the Low German cities; however, it seems to be calm in France, and from Solothurn as well as other places not far from Basel, [mercenaries continue to enter French service]. The meeting [on the Concord issue] already scheduled for September 24th could possibly be postponed at Zurich's request. A Basel resident reports from Brabant that the executed English queen [Anne Boleyn] had a bad reputation; criticism of King [Henry VIII] should be taken with caution. Greetings.

div.p: Greetings. Concerning Utinger, you wrote sorrowful news. May God assist him, I pray, whether he lives or dies.

I hear nothing about the Emperor, except that danger threatens the Swiss Confederates if he emerges victorious. This rumor flies in from all directions. In Brabant, they say: The victorious Emperor will invade the allied cities (the Hanseatic League) in Lower Germany. A certain person from France wrote to me these days about his safety; not a word about the enemy. The French soldiers send a huge amount of gold here. Someone even sent a parrot. From this, they seem to me more than sufficiently secure. From Solothurn and other places neighboring us, there is no end to the excursions.

As for the meeting, it was decided before I approached the consul. The consul said it was scheduled for the coming Sunday before Michaelmas. What if, by the counsel of your people, it could be postponed?

In England, there is peace. About the executed queen, both the English themselves and their neighbors say: "She was a wicked piece of flesh." This is common. Therefore, anyone who speaks ill of the king could be suspect. I say this from a certain godfather of mine, who came from Brabant the day before yesterday.
Farewell with your wife, children, and brothers. If Utinger lives, console him in the Lord or in my name.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, his dearest lord and brother.
